text.sentence: On three/ten/sixteen, the Wall Street Journal reported that TransCanada Corp. is engaged in negotiations regarding a potential takeover of the Columbia Pipeline Group .
While TRP subsequently confirmed that it is in discussion regarding a potential transaction with a third party, the company declined to elaborate further.
Following the initial report, CPGX shares have gained sixteen.three percent while TRP's shares have declined by three.one
At the entities' respective MLPs, trading has been volatile as the market is trying to digest the outlooks for both partnerships but as of Friday's close, CPPL's units have fallen twenty.
Over the same time period, the S and P five hundred has increased one.seven
percent and the Alerian MLP Index has gained one.two percent .
As it stands today, both TRP and the Columbia complex have significant financing needs and each has indicated their intention to use their MLPs as a component of their financing plans.
As the situation unfolds, one of the key topics that investors are attempting to sort out is what role the partnerships would play in the financing plans of a combined TRP/CPGX.
For its part, CPPL offers an equity cost of capital advantage of approximately two hundred fifteen basis points even after the units' recent decline.
On the other hand, TCP offers a more liquid currency which would provide a distinct benefit in the context of potentially large capital raises.

Additionally, TCP's IDR structure caps the max tier at a twenty five percent GP take which over time would reduce the drag of GP payments relative to CPPL whose IDR structure contains the more common fifty percent fifty percent splits.
In the body of this note, we provide a scenario analysis in which we review some of the potential paths forward for TCP, CPPL, and CPGX.

Our analysis covers the following three scenarios: one) CPPL buys TCP, two) TCP buys CPPL, and three) CPPL is rolled into TRP while TCP remains as the surviving partnership and is used as a source of external financing going forward.
Based on our analysis, the first two scenarios result in unattractive outcomes for current TCP unitholders.

Conversely, the third scenario provides TCP with a platform to increase the rate and visibility of its distribution growth, which we think could explain its relative outperformance over the past several days.
Unchanged For a full list of our ratings, price target and earnings changes in this report, please see table on page two.

Barclays | Columbia Pipeline / TC Pipelines, LP Summary of our Ratings, Price Targets and Earnings Changes in this Report

As reports of a potential deal between TRP and CPGX first surfaced, our initial inclination was to think that CPPL would purchase TCP and remain as the surviving partnership, as this has been a trend we've seen for some time.
This approach would also have the added benefit of increasing CPPL's liquidity, a factor which has persistently weighed on the partnership's current equity issuance plans.
We initially interpreted these moves as being consistent with the purchase of TCP by CPPL.
In Figure one below, we illustrate the mechanics of such a transaction, which may explain why the market reversed course mid day.

Before assessing a combination, we felt that it was important to first address the financing of OpCo's FYsixteen cash needs given that any transaction with TRP would likely take some time to close, leaving the Columbia entities on their own to finance their outspend this year.

In lieu of the approximately dollar seven hundred fifty million investment by CPPL in new OpCo equity that we assume in our currently published model, we instead show CPGX lending dollar seven hundred fifty million of cash directly to OpCo via the existing money pool facility.
CPGX currently has ~ dollar eight hundred fifty million of cash on hand following its late two thousand fifteen equity issuance.
In this case, CPPL's interest in OpCo would remain static at fifteen.seven percent throughout the year.
The partnership can still grow its distribution by twenty percent y/y, although coverage would be thin.
From CPPL's perspective, our scenario analysis shows a combination would be accretive and allow the partnership to maintain growth of twenty percent into two thousand seventeen.
However, such a transaction appears to result in a back door cut of TCP's distribution.
CPPL units for each one TCP unit, the implied equivalent distribution received by TCP's unitholders would be dollar three.fifty
three, reflecting a haircut of approximately ten percent compared to the dollar three.ninety
four that we forecast they will receive in FY seventeen under the partnership's existing six.
The level of the haircut is highly sensitive to CPPL's unit price.
At higher prices, the implied haircut forced upon TCP unitholders would grow.

In the event CPPL's price performance were to reverse course from its recent sharp decline, this would paradoxically weaken the economic outcome for TCP's current unitholders which in our view would make this transaction scenario more unlikely.
Additionally, we aren't sure if TransCanada would want to subject its TCP unitholders to a higher GP cut after resetting its own years ago for their benefit.

Not surprisingly, the outcome of this scenario also appears to be unappealing to TCP unitholders.
Exchanging a higher yielding equity currency for one with a lower yield invariably proves to be dilutive.
We note that the outcome below does not contemplate the continuation of dropdowns at TCP which would serve to increase the distribution paid by the partnership.
Nonetheless, we would characterize this outcome as taking two steps back to take one step forward, given that we forecast TCP is already on track to pay distributions of dollar three.seventy

In Scenario Three, we assume that TRP purchases both CPGX and CPPL, while simultaneously continuing to pursue a dropdown strategy at TCP. Contrary to the adverse outcomes for TCP's unitholders implied in the first two scenarios, we think that this approach could actually enable TCP to increase its growth rate above its current six.
Figure three below illustrates an accelerated dropdown strategy where the partnership delivers growth of eight percent p.a. and completes transactions ranging from dollar one.
TCP's current dropdown strategy contemplates the purchase of TRP's remaining U.S. natural gas transportation assets over the next several years.

By the end of FYsixteen, TRP estimates that EBITDA attributable to these assets will reach slightly more than dollar four hundred million, implying visibility into distribution growth until approximately two thousand nineteen.

If TRP were to purchase both CPGX and CPPL, the size of the dropdown inventory would grow by at least ~ dollar one.six billion by the time all of Columbia's growth projects are placed into service in late two thousand eighteen.
We suspect that part of the calculus behind TCP capping its current growth target at six. percent relates to management's hesitancy to earmark other assets for dropdown.
As it stands today, TRP management has not made any sort of commitment to dropping its eligible U.S. liquids assets into the partnership.
With the addition of the Columbia complex, our math shows that TCP could increase its distribution growth rate to at least eight.
percent through the end of the decade relying solely on natural gas exposed assets, at which point it would still have in excess of dollar one.
As always, cost of capital is an important variable in our scenario analysis.
As part of this scenario we have assumed that TCP's yield tightens to six.
Barclays | Columbia Pipeline / TC Pipelines, LP of an increased growth target.
This still reflects a discount of ~sixty bps to SEP, who is currently targeting a three year distribution CAGR of eight.
FIGURE three Scenario Three ­ TCP Accelerates Growth, Supported by EBITDA from CPPL/CPGX

We think CPPL is unlikely to be orphaned as an MLP
Lastly, while it could be possible to simply keep CPPL outstanding while CPGX is purchased, we are inclined to think this isn't a likely scenario.

If CPGX were to be purchased by a party with a stronger balance sheet capable of financing the capex at OpCo with both cash flow and debt, it would reduce the need for CPPL as an equity funding vehicle.
In a scenario where CPPL remained public but was not used as a financing vehicle, CPPL's fifteen.seven
percent interest in OpCo would remain static, and the MLP's only way of growing its distribution would be to wait for OpCo's EBITDA to ramp at the end of the decade.
Leaving CPPL as a publicly traded vehicle would also make it difficult for TRP to drop the remaining eighty four.three
percent of OpCo into TCP at a later point in time as CPPL has a right of first refusal on this interest.
For these reasons, we think the logical course of action is for TRP to buy in CPPL alongside CPGX so that one hundred percent of OpCo would sit at TransCanada.
We believe the market is assuming that CPPL will be orphaned if TransCanada buys CPGX, but we disagree and think CPPL is a buy at these levels.
We would expect some sort of premium to be paid above where the units were trading prior to the news of a potential transaction between TRP and CPGX.
In some respects, we also think a deal is a must do from Columbia's perspective, as subsequent sell off of CPPL could have severely impaired the value of the currency on a more permanent basis.
In the event no deal is executed, investors may be increasingly hesitant to bid up the price of CPPL once again, knowing that something similar could occur again in the future.

Since its spin off from NiSource, we have repeatedly been asked about the types of companies that would be interested in purchasing a company like Columbia given the attractive assets in its portfolio, its growth profile, and management's openness to a sale.
The ideal candidate would be someone with a strong balance sheet.
Columbia has over ninety percent + of its cash flow generated from firm contracts, primarily supported by the take or pay type of revenues collected by its interstate gas pipelines.

It is positioned to grow its EBITDA at a twenty percent CAGR through two thousand twenty, underpinned by ~ dollar eight billion of capex, the majority of which is earmarked for expansions of existing pipeline syste Miss Most of the contracts for these expansions are also subject to take or pay agreements, with many carrying tenors of as long as twenty years.
Since CPPL's IPO and CPGX's spin off, the persistent issue the complex has faced lies with the magnitude of its financing needs and its limited balance sheet capacity.

The system's capital needs exceed the cash flow currently being generated, and due to the leverage of the combined entities, the amount of debt that can be raised is limited if it would like to keep its investment grade rating.

While credit rating agencies have usually allowed some level of project credit when determining the leverage for other companies under our coverage, Columbia has not had the benefit of receiving this type of support due to its limited track record of execution as a stand alone company following the spinoff from its predecessor.
As a result of the inevitable equity needs, Columbia went public with CPPL in early two thousand fifteen due to the lower cost of equity it expected to obtain in the MLP market.
Not long after, access to the capital market became more limited as a result of what was going on in the general energy sector, and the currency of the MLP has deteriorated in value.
While off its lows and attractive in the relative sense, CPGX would still have to make concessions on the valuation of any new equity in OpCo that would be purchased by the MLP.

Said another way, CPPL's initial investments in OpCo should be made at multiples in the high teens as it is buying an interest in an entity that will be growing EBITDA by twenty percent p.a through the end of the decade, but the MLP has been trading at a level where it can't afford such a valuation and still have
Barclays | Columbia Pipeline / TC Pipelines, LP any purchase be accretive enough to deliver its promised distribution growth of twenty percent .
Without a material recovery in the CPPL unit price, CPGX would have had to do the first transaction at a lower multiple with the hopes of jumpstarting CPPL.

We think CPGX shareholders will likely require a portion of the consideration in cash and with CPGX's leverage lower than TransCanada, the latter would be able to add a small amount of debt to do so without materially impacting its current credit metrics.
For TransCanada, TCP is an important financing source for the Company but dropdowns into the MLP have been and still remain a function of the funding needs at the parent.

While TransCanada has dollar thirteen billion of visible near term projects, the backlog behind that has shrunk with the denial of the presidential permit for Keystone XL, which was supposed to be an dollar eight billion investment.

In a scenario where TRP purchased CPGX, there would be at least dollar six.five billion of growth capex from two thousand seventeen two thousand twenty, with peak spending in two thousand seventeen and two thousand eighteen partially filling the hole created by Keystone XL no longer moving forward.

If the reported WSJ deal goes ahead, with TransCanada taking on the capex for OpCo, we think TCP's yield could come in as the market calibrates the funding shortfall at the parent, which could accelerate the dropdowns into the MLP and support a higher growth than the ~six.
Importantly, we would also highlight that TCP wouldn't be subject to the issues that CPPL is currently facing regarding the high multiples that we mention above.
TransCanada has a number of natural gas pipelines earmarked for dropdown into the MLP and we expect these assets to remain at the front of the queue for sale into the MLP.
Given that these assets are mature and offer stable cash flows, we suspect they would be dropped for approximately nine.x ten.x.
This would be similar to the valuations we've seen historically and support cash flow accretion.
With these assets available for drop, the pressure associated with improving CPPL's valuation inside of a four.
percent yield to enable OpCo sales at high teens multiples would be eliminated.
As noted above, TRP's current natural gas asset inventory would support dropdowns for several years, after which most of Columbia's existing growth projects will be cash flowing.
At this point, these assets would be primed to be dropped at more normalized valuations as well.
Essentially what a potential purchase of CPGX and CPPL would do for TRP, in our view, is extend the inventory of drops for TCP, with TRP incubating OpCo's projects in the meantime.
U.S. Diversified Natural Gas Industry View: NEUTRAL Stock Rating: EQUAL WEIGHT CAGR twenty six.one percent forty nine.
percent N/A Price USD twenty two.ninety six Price Target USD twenty one.
We rate CPGX Equal Weight due to its levered balance sheet, which will inhibit it from paying out all of its cash flow via dividend, and instead reinvest a portion into new projects.
Dividend growth will likely accelerate through the years, but we estimate will only be six.
percent in two thousand sixteen and ten percent in two thousand seventeen before moving higher.
If we were to assume seventy fivex for the GP in two thousand eighteen, and our upside case's per share value for CPPL of dollar twenty one, CPGX's implied share price is dollar twenty four.
If we were to assume fortyx for the GP in two thousand eighteen, and our downside case's per share value for CPPL of dollar twelve, CPGX's implied share price is dollar seventeen.

We rate CPPL with an Overweight rating as we think the recent stock sell off tied to the equity overhang has been overdone.
CPPL has a robust backlog of projects that will support twenty percent distribution growth through at least two thousand nineteen with minimal commodity and volume exposure .
Our upside case assumes the same distribution as our base case, but uses a target yield of four.six
percent, ~fiftybps wide of DM's currently implied two thousand seventeen yield.
Our downside case assumes the company is only able to deliver distribution growth of twelve.five
percent p.a. resulting in an implied two thousand seventeen payout of dollar .eighty

Our Equal Weight rating reflects our expectation that TCP's existing asset base and inventory of assets eligible for dropdown from its parent will support distribution growth at a six.

Our downside case is based on the same two thousand seventeene distribution as our base case, except assumes the units trade at a yield of nine.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.

Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.

At any given time, its associated Designated Market Maker may have long or short inventory position in the stock; and its associated Designated Market Maker may be on the opposite side of orders executed on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the stock.

Valuation Methodology: Our dollar twenty one price target is predicated on a sum of the parts: one) dollar six.three billion for CPGX's value of OpCo; two) dollar one.nine billion for the one hundred one million LP units we estimated CPGX will own by two thousand seventeen at a dollar nineteen PT, and three) dollar three.one billion for the GP of CPPL less dollar two.nine billion of debt, divided by four hundred million shares.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Customer concentration, commodity exposure, credit risk, regulatory risk, acquisition risk, event risk, and capital markets risk.
